course_title: Law in the Criminal Justice System

learning_outcomes.description: Understand the structure and origin of the Australian legal system.
Appreciate the importance of fundamental legal principles and political structures and how they apply to criminal justice system institutions and processes.
Analyse and critically evaluate different theoretical approaches underpinning legal principles and their application to the criminal justice system.
Apply skills required to engage in effective legal research and analysis of case law, legislation, and secondary sources.
Apply skills required to communicate effectively within a legal and policy context.

assessments.task_description:
In week one of semester, students will be provided with a list of discussion questions covering content from weeks 1-3. They must select ONE of the questions and write a short essay in response. A detailed instruction sheet and marking criteria will also be made available in week 1 of semester.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Finding, Reading, and Interpreting Law: Worksheet
assessments.task_description:
In week 5 of semester, students will be provided with a worksheet containing a set of questions and activities covering content from weeks 5 and 6. These questions and activities will allow students to demonstrate their ability to find relevant law, to identify elements of criminal offences, and to read and interpret case law. A detailed instruction sheet and marking criteria will also be made available in week 5.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.assessment_title: Police and Pre-trial Decision-Making: Problem-based questions
assessments.task_description:
Students will be provided with case scenarios followed by a set of questions about the legal issues that arise from each scenario. Students must identify each relevant issue, explain the applicable law correctly, apply the relevant law to the scenario facts, and conclude on the issue. Questions may also ask students to critically reflect on the issues arising.

In week 8 of semester, students will be provided with problem-based questions covering content from weeks 8 and 9, together with instructions and marking criteria. The skills required to complete a problem-based question will be rehearsed in class in weeks 8 and 9 to support the completion of this assessment item. 

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.assessment_title: End-of-Semester Examination: Trial, Sentencing, and Appeals
assessments.task_description:
The final exam comprises two problem-based questions. This assessment task builds on the skills developed in Assessment 3 and applies these skills to the content covered in weeks 10-12. Instructions and marking criteria will be made available in Week 10.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
